channel.title: Engaging Gospel Doctrine: Older episodes
channel.description: Engaging Gospel Doctrine provides supplementary resources for Latter-Day Saint Sunday School.

item.description: This portion of the Creation episode explores

item.title: 272.2: The Wonder of Creation (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 3, Sunday School)
item.description: Appreciating the miracle of creation and our responsibility relating to it proves more important than understanding its mechanics, but the latter remains valuable.

item.title: 272.1: The Wonder of Creation (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 3, Updated)
item.description: Guess what? You are able to read this because you exist! (And are literate and have access to the internet).

item.title: 271.3: Pre-Existence and Book of Abraham (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 2, Study Notes)
item.description: This “Study Notes” portion on the Book of Abraham explores this book of scripture from a literary and historical perspective, and explains why some people have a hard time reconciling an academic approach with the way the Book of Abraham is presented in Church. A discussion of the purpose of scripture and the nature of inspiration brings the two perspectives together.

item.title: 271.2: Pre-Existence and Book of Abraham (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 2, Sunday School)
item.description: The Book of Abraham commands fascination, with its theological distinctiveness (plurality of gods and teaching about the pre-existence) and connections to the Egyptian papyri. Not everyone may be aware that many struggle with this book of scripture, however. This episode digs deeply into the value of the Book of Abraham theologically, focusing on teachings about the pre-existence and foreordination. We also explore the implications of the relationship between scripture and history.

item.title: 271.1: Pre-Existence and Book of Abraham (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 2, Updated)
270.3: Of God and Humans (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1, Study Notes)
item.description: This lesson only covers thirty-nine verses, but contains profound doctrine. Specifically, these verses illuminate the nature of God, humanity, revelation, and the Plan of Salvation.

item.title: 270.2: Of God and Humans (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1, Sunday School)
item.description: This lesson only covers thirty-nine verses, but contains profound doctrine. Specifically, these verses illuminate the nature of God, humanity, revelation, and the Plan of Salvation.

item.title: 270.1: Of God and Humans (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1, Updated)
269.2: Introduction to the Old Testament (OT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 0)

268.2: Zion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 46)
268.1: Zion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 46, Updated)
267.2: Family (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45)
item.description: Is there anything more important than our relationships? This lessons digs deep into the principles behind healthy relationships, with a focus on marriage and parenting. This is a “two-tone” episode… we model the type of discussion that would fit in a Sunday School environment, and then discuss some of the trickier issues that might come up in private discussion. There is something for everyone here.

item.title: 267.1: Family (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45, Updated)
266.2: Making a Difference (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 44)
item.description: Being a good citizen in essence means to make the world a better place. In this episode, we discuss:

item.title: 266.1: Making a Difference (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 44, Updated)
item.description: One of the most distressing paradoxes of being human is that the more important an issue is, the harder it is to consistently care and engage. Politics governs our day to day lives, and supposedly we live in a democracy, right? And yet the prospect of becoming involved in our community, let alone changing it for the better, often feels overwhelming. This episode discusses starting points for becoming a better citizen, which starts with becoming a better person.

item.title: 265.2: God Training (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 43)
265.1: God Training (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 43, Updated)
264.2: Continuing Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 42)
264.1: Continuing Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 42, Updated)
263.2: Conversion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 41)
263.1: Conversion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 41, Updated)
item.description: Inevitably, we all feel anxious about missionary work whenever it comes up in Church. Are we doing enough? Why haven’t our friends joined the church yet? Why do some of us not have many friends who aren’t members? This update explores the counterintuitive nature of missionary work, which is an on-the-ground demonstration of the paradoxical nature of the gospel. The best way to be a missionary is to not focus on being a missionary. Instead, effective missionary work stems from deeply internalized gospel living and authentic friendships.

item.title: 262.2: Family History (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 40)
item.description: Can we be saved through stories? This episode explores the stories we tell, as we record our own experiences, document the stories of family members, and “redeem our dead”–first by rediscovering them and keeping their stories alive and then doing their temple work.

item.title: 262.1: Family History (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 40, Updated)
261.2: Redeeming the Living and the Dead (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 39)
item.description: Previous episodes on the temple have discussed

item.title: 261.1: Redeeming the Living and the Dead (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 39, Updated)
item.description: If the dead didn’t need your temple service, how often would you attend? This updated episode invites an honest look at our relationship to the temple and explores how temple attendance benefits us, the living.

item.title: 260.2: Providing for ourselves and each other (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 38)
item.description: One of the most urgent problems we face today is also the most overwhelming… incomprehensible wealth inequality and literally a world of desperate need. This episode discusses

item.title: 260.1: Providing for ourselves and each other (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 38, Updated)
item.description: What image comes to mind when we talk about “caring for the poor and needy”? Probably something like feeding the homeless or a destitute family in Africa. Those people are poor and needy of course, but focusing on such individuals distracts us from the truth that all of us are wealthy in some ways, poor in others, and all of us are in need. This episode invites us to take an inventory of our resources–physical, mental, emotional, spiritual, relational, and financial; become wise stewards of our resources, and then care for others as we can.

item.title: 259.2: Prophets (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 37)
item.description: The principles of revelation and authority intersect in complex ways. We believe that God speaks to *all* of their children through personal revelation. At the same time, only one prophet is authorized to share God’s will to the world. Finally, we are taught that God also inspires spiritual leaders outside the faith. How do we balance these elements?

item.title: 259.1: Prophets (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 37, Updated)
item.description: Who is your favorite prophet? Do you feel particularly close to any prophet from scripture? Because the purpose of the gospel is to bring salvation to all of us, God speaks to all people, in all nations (2 Ne. 29; Alma 29:8). Thus it makes sense that there are prophets both familiar to us and those we do not yet know.

item.title: 258.2: Arrival in Utah (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 36)
258.1: Arrival in Utah (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 36, Updated)
257.2: Handcart Companies (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 35)
item.description: Even among the pioneer stories, no image is more iconic or moving than the pioneers who traveled not by wagon, but by handcart. And we are sobered and inspired as we hear the story of tragedy and rescue surrounding the Martin and Willie handcart companies. This episode explores these important stories and discussion will cover the following:

item.title: 257.1: Handcart Companies (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 35, Updated)
256.2: Crossing the Plains (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 34)
item.description: The story of the pioneers crossing the plains has a special role in Mormon life and culture. This episode discusses this history, focusing on Winter Quarters and Brigham Young’s role. The class explores the questions of what we can learn from the pioneers, and how we can honor their authentic experiences as well as our own. Specific points of discussion include:

item.title: 256.1: Crossing the Plains (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 34, Updated)
item.description: The story of the Saints crossing the plains to arrive in Utah has become a pilgrimage of heritage and imagination. Our minds follow their feet that brought them and the gospel across the United States. In addition, the pioneer spirit applies to all members of the Church, all humans… we all come from pioneers, and we are pioneers in our own right. And often we learn and change the most from our own “Crossing the plains” experiences.

item.title: 255: Brigham Young and the Succession; D&C and Church History 33
item.description: This episode addresses the topic of prophetic succession in the Mormon tradition as well as the complex character of Brigham Young. The lesson and discussion cover the following topics:

item.title: 254.2: The Martyrdom of Joseph and Hyrum (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 32)
254.1: The Martyrdom of Joseph and Hyrum (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 32, Updated)
253.2: Marriage in Heaven and Earth (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 31)
item.description: No human relationship is as focused on, celebrated, and debated as marriage. But what is the relationship between our marriage now and union in the eternities? What was the development between marriage in the Bible, early Church, and present day? Get ready for one of the most interesting episodes ever as a unique class discusses:

item.title: 253.1: Marriage in Heaven and Earth (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 31, Updated)
252.2: Redeeming the Dead (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 30)
252.1: Redeeming the Dead (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 30, Updated)
item.description: Have you ever been curious about the importance of temple work for the dead? Why is it so urgent? Specifically, why is performing vicarious ordinances for the dead worth sacrificing hours of our life, here and now? This episode discusses the ways in which temple work helps those of us who are living, as we all work together toward becoming like our Heavenly Parents.

item.title: 251.2: The Church in Nauvoo (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 29)
251.1: The Church in Nauvoo (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 29, Updated)
250.2: Suffering and Pain (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 28)
item.description: Why? Why me? Why my loved one? Why any of us? Where is God? There are no more poignant questions in life. This may prove to be the most important episode we even produce, as it explores our deepest question–why life is so hard. So unfair. So painful. This lesson and discussion will explore:

item.title: 250.1: Suffering and Pain (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 28, Updated)
item.description: Why is life so hard? Why do we hurt so much? Is there any way to suffer less? These are important questions to answer… but we can only answer for ourselves. When it comes to the suffering of others, our covenental obligation is clear: to show up, sit with them, and see them through.

item.title: 249.2: Trials, Failure, and Mistakes (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 27)
item.description: This lesson doesn’t waste any time striking to the heart of difficult issues. This lesson will discuss such important topics as:

item.title: 249.1: Trials, Mistakes, and Failure (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 27, Updated)
248.2: Sharing the Gospel (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 26)
248.1: Sharing the Gospel (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 26, Updated)
247.4: Priesthood (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 25)
247.3: Priesthood (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 25, Updated)
item.description: The concept of priesthood is central to the LDS faith, but what *is* it exactly? Priesthood is the presence and power of God, manifest on earth.

item.title: 247.2: Apostasy (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 24)
item.description: It is time to address the tricky topic of individual “apostasy”–falling away from God and the Church. Are the two the same? Can you do one without the other? What does “being deceived” mean in this context? What is the relationship between doubt and apostasy?

item.title: 247.1: Apostasy (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 24, Updated)
246.2: A World of Learning (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 23)
item.description: In a sense, this lesson provides a foundation of all others. How do we understand ourselves, each other, and the world around us? How do we learn? What is the role of “study” and what is the role of “faith”? What are the strengths and limitations of each approach? This lesson will explore two primary questions:

item.title: 246.1: A World of Learning (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 23, Updated)
item.description: Combining study and faith actually is quite challenging. Without the right approach, study can indeed destroy faith. This episode explores what is most important for us to learn, how we learn, and how we can learn by study and faith in a constructive way.

item.title: 245.2: Law of Health (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 22)
item.description: We are what we eat (Or even better in German, Man ist, was man isst). This proverb is quite literally true biologically, but also bears social truth–we are who we eat with. Food shapes us physically, spiritually, and socially. The Word of Wisdom is known as the “Lord’s law of health,” as well as creating social distinctions and emphasizing obedience. At the same time, too rarely do members consider the principles behind this requirement past the short list of “don’ts”. In this episode, we will discuss:

item.title: 245.1: Law of Health (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 22, Updated)
244.2: The Second Coming of Jesus (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 21)
item.description: I know I often use superlatives relating to these lessons, but this topic might deserve a few. Is there any topic more thrilling and discussion provoking as the Second Coming? When I subbed youth Sunday School and asked for questions, the Second Coming was a requested topic. This is blockbuster movie material. And it has been.

item.title: 244.1: The Second Coming of Jesus (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 21, Updated)
243.2: Heaven on Earth (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 20)
item.description: One of the gospel’s great contributions is its expansive, detailed, and powerful description of the Plan of Salvation–encompassing more than simply the afterlife, the scriptures describe multiple steps–the pre-existence, earth life, the spirit world, and then the kingdoms of glory. In this episode we will

item.title: 243.1: Heaven on Earth (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 20, Updated)
242.2: The Plan of Salvation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 19)

239.2: Sabbath and Sacred Time (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 16)
item.description: The pace of modern life is unrelenting. Too many of us never stop. We never rest. We are always available, always on call–a text message away from work and distraction. There is wisdom is pausing, stopping for a moment, having times of quiet and reflection. And this is the purpose of the Sabbath, a term that means “to stop or rest.”

item.title: 239.1: Sabbath and Sacred Time (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 16, Updated)
238.2: Differing Gifts (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 15)
item.description: Recurring Donation:

item.title: 238.1: Differing Gifts (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 15, Updated)
237.2: Giving the Kingdom Our All (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 14)
item.description: Why is “mine!” often among our first words? One of the most sensitive, difficult, and important questions involves resource allocation. Who gets what? Who has the right to what? Is there a minimum of resources that every person deserves? What level of inequality is ethical? What makes possession ethical?

item.title: 237.1: Giving the Kingdom Our All (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 14, Updated)
item.description: If we give everything we have and are, what is left? Too often we either ignore the idea of the Law of Consecration or we use it to discount our own needs, giving and giving until we are completely burned out. This episode emphasizes sustainable, transformative consecration. I believe that God wants us to care for ourselves, those close to us, our Church and communities in a way that allows us to gain more and become more as we serve.

item.title: 236.2: What is Scripture? (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 13)
236.1: What is Scripture? (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 13, Updated)
235.2: Homecoming (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 12)
item.description: Belonging is one of our greatest human needs, and there aren’t many more poignant and powerful ideas than that of “coming home.” This lesson will explore the concept of “gathering”, or more poetically put, our Heavenly Parents bringing us together so we can help each other come home. We will discuss:

item.title: 235.1: Homecoming (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 12, Updated)
234.2: Missionary Work Past, Present, Future (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 11)
234.1: Missionary Work Past, Present, Future (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 11, Updated)
233.2: Scripture Stories (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 10)
item.description: The theme of this lesson is to “liken the scriptures to ourselves”, which means it is about nothing less than how to study the scriptures. How do we apply the scriptures to our lives? How do we determine what to focus on, what is valuable? What is our standard to determine which stories are good examples, and which bad?

item.title: 233.1: Scripture Stories (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 10, Updated)
232.2: True and Living Religion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 9)
232.1: True and Living Religion (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 9, Updated)
231.2: Restoration of the Priesthood (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 8)
item.description: The priesthood permeates pretty much everything we do in the LDS Church. Much of the reason to be a member is tied up in the power and authority restored through Joseph Smith, culminating in saving temple ordinances. For these reasons, this lesson is a very important one. I confess that this is a lesson I have wrestled with how to teach responsibly–the subject of power and authority from God is very important, but our sources and the history behind them get complicated and messy. This lesson will cover:

item.title: 231.1: Restoration of the Priesthood (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 8, Updated)
230.2: Personal Gospel Principles (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 7)
230.1: Personal Gospel Principles (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 7, Updated)
229.2: Interpreting Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 6)
item.description: In this lesson we will discuss a topic of vital importance. How do we interpret revelation? How do we distinguish inspiration from God and our own thoughts, feelings, and desires? Once we can identify that we are receiving a prompting from a source greater than ourselves, how do we interpret it? How should we act on it? What is the relationship of personal revelation and teachings revealed through scripture and Church leaders?

item.title: 229.1: Interpreting Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 6, Updated)
228.2: Receiving Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 5)
item.description: I would submit that the topic of the next two lessons is the single most important subject in all the gospel. Simply put, revelation is our access to everything else. It is our conduit and connection to spiritual life, to inspiration, to wisdom and guidance. It is the key to learning, to living well and serving others.

item.title: 228.1: Receiving Revelation (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 5, Updated)

item.title: 224.1: Introduction to the D&C and Church History (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1, Update)
223: Additional Church History Resources (D&C Gospel Doctrine Lesson 00)
222: Faith, Hope, Love (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 48)
item.description: So much to discuss as we conclude our study of the Book of Mormon this year. Points we will explore this lesson:

item.title: 220: An Eye of Faith (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 46)
item.description: This lesson contains one of the crown jewels of the Book of Mormon–the sublime verse on weakness and strength in 12:27. There are other gems worthy of study, discussion, and application in this chapter. We have the idea that we can be the angels whom God uses to answer prayers, and Moroni comments on how God speaks to us within our language and limitations (12:39; cf. 2 Ne. 31:3), and of course his treatise on faith.

item.title: 219: Journey to the Promised Land (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 45)
item.description: In this lesson we get to discuss the sealed portion of the Book of Mormon (which made up the bulk of the plates as Joseph described them)! What is contained in the sealed portion? What can we learn from the instructions regarding how to access them?

item.title: 218: Last Nephite Standing (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 44)
item.description: After Mormon’s final plea to the House of Israel, Moroni takes over the record. His despair and loneliness is palpable and touching in the beginning of Mormon 8. There are several thought provoking gems in these chapters about weakness, pride, caring for the needy, and theological points about the nature of God and judgment.

item.title: 217: The Problem of Evil (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 43)
216: Utopia and Collapse (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 42)
item.description: These chapters include an account of the happiest, most righteous, productive years in all of Book of Mormon history, the model utopian society that endured almost two hundred years after Jesus’ appearance. Unfortunately, we only read about that time period (which surpasses the time covered by Mosiah, Alma, Helaman, and 3 Nephi!) for eighteen brief verses. Why don’t we have more about this ideal period? How much could we learn from such a successful society? What can we apply from the details we have?

200.2: Burying Our Weapons of War (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 26, Complete)
item.description: Here is the full episode on Lesson 26. These chapters tell of conversions through miraculous and even troubling means, inspiring devotion to principle, and overwhelming joy. We also have angel-wannabe Alma teaching us a powerful truth about God calling prophets among all people.

item.title: 200.1: Burying Our Weapons of War (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 26, Core)

197: Theodicy of the Unbearable (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 24)

195: Introspection and Atonement (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 22)
item.description: Alma has some impressive rhetorical skills on display in his interrogative sermon in chapter 5. He encourages his audience to access their past selves, future selves, ideal selves, and imagine dying and standing accountable before God.

item.title: 194: Kings, Judges, and War (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 21)
193: The Conversion of Alma the Younger (BoM Gospel Doctrine Lesson 20)
item.description: We all know the story of the conversion of Alma the Younger, but too rarely pause and ask the deeper questions that add richness and applicability to this narrative. Why did Alma want to destroy the Church? If God can send an angel ex machina to convince someone of their existence, why doesn’t that happen more often? What other lessons can we draw from Alma’s dramatic conversion?

170: God is Love (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 44)
169: 1-2 Peter; Jude (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 43)
item.description: 1-2 Peter and Jude yield themselves to the “finding nuggets” approach, and there are important ones, such as being prepared to explain your hope and beliefs as well as addressing the issues of suffering, scriptural interpretation, and “false teaching”.

item.title: 168: Faith and Works (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 42)
item.description: Perhaps a better question than “are we saved by faith or works?” is “How can we save others through our faith and works?

item.title: 167: The Pastoral Letters (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 41)
item.description: The books of 1 and 2 Timothy have some good advice about how to be an effective leader. They also have some problematic advice, especially concerning women and slaves. The thing is, even the good advice doesn’t sound like what Paul would say. This episode covers the author’s council on leadership, warnings against non-constructive discussions and knowledge, and the iconic lines about having “fought the good fight” don’t quite capture the meaning of the Greek.

item.title: 166: Anything Praiseworthy (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 40)
165: Ephesians (New Testament Gospel of Doctrine Lesson 39)
164: The Trials of Paul (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 38)
163: Jesus, the Great High Priest (NT Gospel Doctrine 37)
162: Paul to the Romans (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 36)
161: Be Reconciled to God (NT Gospel Doctrine Lesson 35)
item.description: 2 Corinthians contains some powerful words of comfort, as well as surprising insights about the benefits of weakness.

item.title: 160: Corinthian Crises (New Testament Gospel Doctrine Lesson 34)
item.description: The Corinthian church was rife with problems–division, debate, lawsuits, immorality, and trying to outperform each other with spiritual gifts. Paul argues that in the end, all you need is love.

item.title: 159: Ye Are the Temple of God (New Testament Lesson 33)
item.description: What does it mean that we are “the temple of God”? How can the idea of being “not our own” be both positive and negative? This episode explores these issues in the context of 1 Corinthians. Yes, we are our own–but also accountable to something greater.

item.title: 158: Fruits of the Spirit (New Testament Lesson 32)
157: Establishment of the Church (New Testament Lesson 31)
156: Partiality, God, and Humans (New Testament Lesson 30)
item.description: This lesson explores the tension between perspectives divine and human–we learn that God loves all and does not even prefer one group to another (“All are alike unto God”), but humans on the other hand prove profoundly tribal. Peter’s vision prompting the spread of the gospel to the Gentiles prompts discussion.

item.title: 155: Growth of the Church (New Testament Lesson 29)
item.description: This lesson covers the growth of the Jesus Movement (or “Way”) from Jerusalem to the ends of the earth, centering on the surprising conversion of Saul, who would become the Apostle to the Gentiles.

item.title: 154: Witnesses for Christ (New Testament Lesson 28)
item.description: This mini-episode discusses how we can bear witness of Christ and the gospel effectively, as well as the relationship between apostolic and individual witness. See also the previous episodes on

item.title: 153: Resurrection (New Testament Lesson 27)
item.description: The resurrection provides a triumphant high note for the gospels and hope in our own lives. This episode discusses each gospel account and how afterlife impacts us while we still live.

item.title: 152: Death of Jesus (New Testament Lesson 26)
item.description: This episode explores the lessons we can learn from Jesus’ death, as well as how we can accept death in a way that enriches life.

item.description: Wisdom Literature” represents ancient attempts to understand, describe and transmit secrets to living well (perhaps something like ancient self-help books?). This episode

item.title: 107: Temple, Law, and Reform; OT Lesson 30 (Mini-Episode)
item.description: The assigned scriptures speak of temple and Law, but the underlying lesson is one of reform and resolution, making changes and becoming better. I suggest keeping the discussion points in mind as you read and prepare:

item.title: 106: Elisha and Prophetic Succession; OT Lesson 29 (Mini-Episode)
item.description: This is the first of three episodes I am covering minimally so that we can get ahead of schedule. This episode provides pointers on teaching this lesson and covers topics such as prophets and succession and miracles through the little things in life.

item.title: 105.2: Elijah and the Still Small Voice; OT Lesson 28 (Study Notes)
item.description: Dr. Sheldon Greaves continues discussing Elijah from a literary and historical perspective.

item.title: 105.1: Elijah and the Still Small Voice; OT Lesson 28 (Core)
item.description: Dr. Sheldon Greaves teaches this lesson, which addresses topics such as revelation, divine intervention, and miracles in the context of Elijah’s ministry.

item.title: 104.2: Wicked and Righteous Leaders; OT Lesson 27 (Study Notes)
item.description: As human beings, we are attuned to authority, and leaders can inspire us to do things we otherwise would not–for good and ill. This lesson uses the examples of kings of Israel and Judah to teach lessons on leadership. This section covers:

item.description: Solomon is known as a “man of wisdom”, but if so, why did he make so many mistakes? This lesson explores Solomon and his gifts in historical context. This section covers:

item.title: 102.2: Psalms and Gratitude; OT Lesson 25 (Study Notes)
item.description: Music permeates our lives in addition to playing a central role in our worship. This lesson explores the “hymn book” of ancient Israel as well as music more broadly. This portion also explores gratitude, a central theme of the Psalms and principle of the gospel.

item.title: 102.1: Psalms and Gratitude; OT Lesson 25 (Core)
item.description: Music permeates our lives in addition to playing a central role in our worship. This lesson explores the “hymn book” of ancient Israel as well as music more broadly. This portion also explores gratitude, a central theme of the Psalms and principle of the gospel.

item.title: 101.2: David and Bathsheba; OT Lesson 24 (Study Notes)
item.description: In intimate, tragic detail these passages present the story of David’s greatest mistakes. This most fully described character provides opportunity to engage with difficult but unavoidably important topics.

item.title: 101.1: David and Bathsheba; OT Lesson 24 (Core)
item.description: In intimate, tragic detail these passages present the story of David’s greatest mistakes. This most fully described character provides opportunity to engage with difficult but unavoidably important topics.

item.title: 100:2: Friendship; OT Lesson 23 (Study Notes)
item.description: The story of the faithful friendship between Jonathan and David, destined political opponents who instead became dear friends, is a masterpiece of storytelling. Once again, these powerful examples rest on historical realities far more complex and even troubling. This portion of the episode discusses:

item.title: 100:1: Friendship; OT Lesson 23 (Core)

item.title: 099.2: The Rise of David; OT Lesson 22 (Study Notes)
item.description: King David proves arguably the most complex and relatable character in the entire Bible. Stories of his life are tragically well told, and paint over a history even darker and more complex, if such a thing is possible. This episode covers David’s selection as future king, battle with Goliath, and beginning steps towards his role as the one of the most famous kings in history.

item.title: 099.1: The Rise of David; OT Lesson 22 (Core)
item.description: King David proves arguably the most complex and relatable character in the entire Bible. Stories of his life are tragically well told, and paint over a history even darker and more complex, if such a thing is possible. This episode covers David’s selection as future king, battle with Goliath, and beginning steps towards his role as the one of the most famous kings in history.

item.title: 098.2: Honoring God; OT Lesson 21 (Study Notes)
item.description: What does it mean that God will honor us? What does it mean to honor God? This section touches on Samuel in historical context, contributes a thoughtful correction to consider from last episode, and parses out the purpose according to the lesson manual.

item.title: 098.1: Honoring God; OT Lesson 21 (Core)
item.description: What does it mean that God will honor us? What does it mean to honor God? This episode explores these questions in the context of the story of Samuel, as well as the important question of how we can balance our needs with those of others.

item.title: 097.2: Ruth, Woman of Valor; OT Lesson 20 (Study Notes)
item.description: The little book of Ruth, one of the masterpieces of Biblical literature, teaches profound and challenging principles. Themes include not overlooking those we consider outsiders and the power of steadfast love to restore that which is lost. This portion of the episode covers:

item.title: 097.1: Ruth, Woman of Valor; OT Lesson 20 (Core)
item.description: The little book of Ruth, one of the masterpieces of Biblical literature, teaches profound and challenging principles. Themes include not overlooking those we consider outsiders and the power of steadfast love to restore that which is lost. This portion of the episode covers:

item.title: 096.2: Judges; OT Lesson 19 (Study Notes)
item.description: The book of Judges presents a hodgepodge of redemption and anarchy, all leading up to theme of the need for a king in Israel (kind of a teaser for the King David sequel). This portion of the episode covers:

item.title: 096.1: Judges; OT Lesson 19 (Core)
item.description: The book of Judges presents a hodgepodge of redemption and anarchy, all leading up to theme of the need for a king in Israel (kind of a teaser for the King David sequel). This portion of the episode covers:

item.title: 095.2: Be Strong and of Good Courage; OT Lesson 18 (Study Notes)
item.description: Most of us know the story of Joshua from childhood. The walls came tumbling down, remember? Upon closer examination however, the book of Joshua is very much a mixed bag, offering both inspiration and difficulty. This portion covers:

item.title: 095.1: Be Strong and of Good Courage; OT Lesson 18 (Core)
item.description: Most of us know the story of Joshua from childhood. The walls came tumbling down, remember? Upon closer examination however, the book of Joshua is very much a mixed bag, offering both inspiration and difficulty. This portion covers:

item.title: 094.2: Farewell of Moses; OT Lesson 17 (Study Notes)
item.description: This episode continues by discussing the historical background of Deuteronomy and then exploring the science of memory, importance of commemoration, and the way stories can change us. The class also addresses the distinctions between law, commandment, and morality.

item.title: 094.1: Farewell of Moses; OT Lesson 17 (Core)
item.description: In this lesson we bid farewell to one of the Bible greats–the prophet Moses. His speech covers themes of remembrance and obedience. The discussion covers ways we can remember our covenants and commitments to be our best selves and serve each other.

item.title: 093.2: I Cannot Go beyond the Word of the Lord; OT Lesson 16 (Study Notes)
item.description: This portion covers:

item.title: 093.1: I Cannot Go beyond the Word of the Lord; OT Lesson 16 (Core)
item.description: Balaam’s argument with his donkey has to be one of the most memorable stories from the Old Testament, but it will surprise you how many profound lessons can be drawn from this little story. After all, if you read closely, this is a story about an outsider (even mercenary!) prophet being faithful to what he knows is right.

item.title: 092.2: Look to God and Live; OT Lesson 15 (Study Notes)
item.description: n this section we cover:

item.title: 092.1: Look to God and Live; OT Lesson 15 (Core)
item.description: What does it mean to “Look to God and Live”? It sounds nice, but how do we apply it to our lives? This lesson explores this principle through the lenses of Positive Psychology, time management, and balancing individual and institutional revelation.

item.title: 091.2: Law and Ritual; OT Lesson 14 (Study Notes)
item.description: This portion of the episode continues our exploration of the two parts of the Jewish Law: Ritual and morality. We cover

item.title: 091.1: Law and Ritual; OT Lesson 14 (Core)
item.description: Though the 10 Commandments are arguably the most well-known legislation in the history of the Western World, the Jewish Law which they preface has prompted more confusion. This episode puts the Jewish Law in the context of the sacred. We introduce context and concepts behind the Law, discuss how ritual creates sacred space and time, and explore how these elements can enable us to keep the divine in our daily lives.

item.title: 090.2: Passover and Exodus; OT Lesson 13 (Study Notes)
item.description: Part II (Scholarship) explores the Exodus and Passover from literary and historical perspectives. What can we say really happened? How did these stories develop? The symbolism and importance of the Passover in the Bible and Judaism is also discussed.

item.title: 090.1: Passover and Exodus; OT Lesson 13 (Core)
item.description: The Exodus and Passover left an indelible imprint on Jewish memory, and Jesus’ institution of the Last Supper during a Passover meal carried the symbolism into Christianity. Sheldon Greaves hosts his episode which addresses from both scriptural and personal perspectives the following themes:

item.title: 089.2: Joseph in Egypt; OT Lesson 12 (Study Notes)
item.description: Joseph gets into some tight spots, but even when things are hard, they work out for the best. How does that line up with our lives? Our trials can help us grow, but can they ever break us? In this second portion I provide some historical and literary background to the Joseph narrative, and then

item.title: 089.1: Joseph in Egypt; OT Lesson 12 (Core)
item.description: The masterfully written story of Joseph in Egypt is like nothing else in the Bible–it can actually be described as a novella. This touching account also engages with fundamental life questions: What contributes to success? How can our trials and suffering be for our good? How do we find meaning in life? And perhaps most profoundly, how much and in what ways does God intervene in our lives?

item.title: 088.2: Sexual Morality; OT Lesson 11 (Study Notes)
item.description: In this segment we return to the narratives from a literary and historical perspective, discuss LDS approaches to sexuality from a more critical perspective, confront difficult issues such as rape and sexual abuse, and get into more detail about sexual morality.

item.title: 088.1: Sexual Morality; OT Lesson 11 (Core)
item.description: Sexuality is an aspect of life universally experienced but difficult to talk about. And the assigned readings are no exception. This episode engages with the stories of Dinah, Tamar, and Potiphar’s wife and models a constructive approach to talking about sexuality in a Church context. We also discuss both chastity and sexual transgression.

item.title: 087.2: Birthright and Marriage in the Covenant; OT Lesson 10 (Study Notes)
item.description: The episode continues by reviewing Jewish practices of endogamy (marrying within one’s culture), wrestles with challenging or even harmful aspects of LDS approaches to marriage and children, and concludes with a discussion of healthy approaches to relationships.

item.title: 087.1: Birthright and Marriage in the Covenant; OT Lesson 10 (Core)
item.description: What difference does preparing for marriage in the temple make? And how does that relate to the stories of Rebekah and Isaac and Jacob and his wives? This episode reviews these narratives, discusses the relationship between a temple marriage and successful marriage, and reviews the principles of healthy relationships.

item.title: 086.2: The Sacrifice of Isaac; OT Lesson 9 (Study Notes)
item.description: In Part 2 we touch on the place of Isaac in history and then delve into the terrible but widespread practice of human sacrifice in the Ancient Near East.

item.title: 086:1: The Sacrifice of Isaac; OT Lesson 9 (Core)
item.description: Is the story of a parent attempting to kill his child an appropriate way to teach obedience and sacrifice? Familiarity can be comforting, but also dangerous. This episode wrestles with one of the most disturbing stories of the Bible, when God commands Abraham to kill his beloved son Isaac.

item.title: 085.2: Living Righteously in a Wicked World; OT Lesson 8 (Study Notes)
item.description: The episode continues by wrestling with fundamental issues. We dig deeper into the nature of scripture, the question of what is right and wrong, and explore how we can live well even in the midst of opposition. I think this will prove one of the best episodes of Engaging Gospel doctrine because it provides so many resources and ideas on how to live authentically and well.

item.title: 085.1: Living Righteously in a Wicked World; OT Lesson 8 (Core)
item.description: This lesson includes some of the darkest chapters in the Bible. What do we do with such passages? How do we engage with scripture? How do we evaluate the actions of Biblical prophets? What was the sin of Sodom? What is the nature of righteousness and sin? How do we live according to our principles even in an adversarial environment? This episode wrestles with these fundamental issues.

item.title: 84.2: The Abrahamic Covenant; OT Lesson 7 (Study Notes)
item.description: This portion of the episode explores:

item.title: 84.1: The Abrahamic Covenant; OT Lesson 7 (Core)
item.description: In essence, the Abrahamic covenant is about how God uses those who make covenants and live well to bless the lives of all their children. This section introduces Abraham, explores how God works with us in our limitations and weakness, as well as the impact of covenants on our relationship with God and others. Finally, we discuss our responsibility to appreciate our strengths and weaknesses, privileges and limitations and use our blessings to live well and bless the lives of others.

item.title: 083.2: The Flood and Tower of Babel; OT Lesson 6 (Study Notes)
item.description: This episode concludes with

item.title: 083.1: The Flood and Tower of Babel; OT Lesson 6 (Core)
item.description: Class Member Reading: Moses 8:19–30; Genesis 6–9; 11:1–9; Hebrews 11:7

item.title: 82.2: Cain vs. Enoch; OT Lesson 5 (Study Notes)
item.description: Part II of the episode discusses Cain and Abel in literary and historical perspective, then introduces some ancient traditions about Enoch

item.title: 82.1: Cain vs. Enoch; OT Lesson 5 (Core)
item.description: Containing some of the most sublime verses in LDS scripture, these chapters also present a study in contrasts.

item.title: 081.2: The Fall; OT Lesson 4 (Study Notes)
item.description: This portion of the episode discusses the Adam and Eve narrative in historical and literary context, proposes theories of the Fall across the belief spectrum, and brings in insights from psychology to the question of human nature and improvement.

item.title: 081.1: The Fall; OT Lesson 4 (Core)
item.description: We can appreciate the story of Adam and Eve on many levels. It is a story about human nature, about making hard choices, about growing up. This episode explores the role of the Fall in LDS culture and theology, contrasts it with the idea of “original sin”, and comments on the assigned reading, focusing on the themes of agency, maturing, and overcoming the weaknesses of human nature.

item.title: 080.2: The Creation; OT Lesson 3 (Study Notes)
item.description: This portion of the Creation episode explores

item.title: 080.1: The Creation; OT Lesson 3 (Core)
item.description: Appreciating the miracle of creation and our responsibility relating to it proves more important than understanding its mechanics, but the latter remains valuable.

item.title: 079b: Pre-Existence and Book of Abraham; OT Lesson 2 (Core)
item.description: The Book of Abraham commands fascination, with its theological distinctiveness (plurality of gods and teaching about the pre-existence) and connections to the Egyptian papyri. Not everyone may be aware that many struggle with this book of scripture, however. This episode digs deeply into the value of the Book of Abraham theologically, focusing on teachings about the pre-existence and foreordination. We also explore the implications of the relationship between scripture and history.Class Reading:

item.title: 079a: Pre-Existence and Book of Abraham; OT Lesson 2 (Full)
item.description: The Book of Abraham commands fascination, with its theological distinctiveness (plurality of gods and teaching about the pre-existence) and connections to the Egyptian papyri. Not everyone may be aware that many struggle with this book of scripture, however. This episode digs deeply into the value of the Book of Abraham theologically, focusing on teachings about the pre-existence and foreordination. We also explore the implications of the relationship between scripture and history.

item.title: 078b: This is My Work and My Glory; OT lesson 1(Core)
item.description: This lesson only covers thirty-nine verses, but contains profound doctrine. Specifically, these verses illuminate the nature of God, humanity, revelation, and the Plan of Salvation.

item.title: 078a: This is My Work and My Glory; OT lesson 1(Full)
item.description: This lesson only covers thirty-nine verses, but contains profound doctrine. Specifically, these verses illuminate the nature of God, humanity, revelation, and the Plan of Salvation.

item.title: 077: The Historical Jesus
item.description: What does the term “Historical Jesus” mean? Need we be scared of the Jesus of scholarship? How does the quest for the Historical Jesus differ from the Jesus Christ of faith or the man Jesus of Nazareth?

item.title: 076: Introduction to the Old Testament
item.description: We need a preliminary episode before diving in to the manual for the year. In this “Lesson 0”, I go over the manual, provide a brief but intense overview of the Old Testament, talk about issues of faith, and suggest some key resources that will aid you in understanding the Old Testament. Enjoy!

item.title: 075: Zion; D&C and Church History 46
item.description: What exactly is Zion, and how do we achieve it? Is it something we wait for, or must we build it one brick and changed heart at a time? This final episode of the year explores the nature of Zion and how we achieve it.

item.title: 074: The Family; D&C and Church History 45
item.description: Is there anything more important than our relationships? This lessons digs deep into the principles behind healthy relationships, with a focus on marriage and parenting. This is a “two-tone” episode… we model the type of discussion that would fit in a Sunday School environment, and then discuss some of the trickier issues that might come up in private discussion. There is something for everyone here.

item.title: 073: Being Good Citizens; D&C and Church History 44
item.description: Being a good citizen in essence means to make the world a better place. In this episode, we discuss:

item.title: 072: Armor of God; D&C and Church History 43
item.description: We are supposed to put on the Armor of God… but what is the battle? This episode proposes that the battle is one for our agency (an idea that should be familiar!)–our ability to act rather than be acted upon. This episode will discuss:

item.title: 071: Continuing Revelation through Prophets; D&C and Church History 42
item.description: The message that God speaks to us today is certainly needed and comforting, but how does it work? The lesson explores the nature of revelation and broaches the topic of what revelation we have had in the Church, and the discussion digs deeper into these and other issues including:

item.title: 070: Missionary Work III; D&C and Church History 41
069: Family History; D&C and Church History 40
item.description: Can we be saved through stories? This episode explores the stories we tell, as we record our own experiences, document the stories of family members, and “redeem our dead”–first by rediscovering them and keeping their stories alive and then doing their temple work.

item.title: 068: Redeeming the Living and the Dead; D&C and Church History 39
item.description: Previous episodes on the temple have discussed

item.title: 067: Caring for the Needy; D&C and Church History 38
item.description: One of the most urgent problems we face today is also the most overwhelming… incomprehensible wealth inequality and literally a world of desperate need. This episode discusses

item.title: 066: Prophets; D&C and Church History 37
item.description: The principles of revelation and authority intersect in complex ways. We believe that God speaks to *all* of their children through personal revelation. At the same time, only one prophet is authorized to share God’s will to the world. Finally, we are taught that God also inspires spiritual leaders outside the faith. How do we balance these elements?

item.title: 065: The Settling of Utah; D&C and Church History 36
item.description: The discussion covers the following points:

item.title: 064: The Handcart Companies; D&C and Church History 35
item.description: Even among the pioneer stories, no image is more iconic or moving than the pioneers who traveled not by wagon, but by handcart. And we are sobered and inspired as we hear the story of tragedy and rescue surrounding the Martin and Willie handcart companies. This episode explores these important stories and discussion will cover the following:

item.title: 063: Crossing the Plains; D&C and Church History 34
item.description: The story of the pioneers crossing the plains has a special role in Mormon life and culture. This episode discusses this history, focusing on Winter Quarters and Brigham Young’s role. The class explores the questions of what we can learn from the pioneers, and how we can honor their authentic experiences as well as our own. Specific points of discussion include:

item.title: 062: Brigham Young and the Succession; D&C and Church History 33
item.description: This episode addresses the topic of prophetic succession in the Mormon tradition as well as the complex character of Brigham Young. The lesson and discussion cover the following topics:

item.title: 061: The Martyrdom of Joseph Smith; D&C and Church History 32
item.description: How is your life different because of an obscure farmboy born in 1805 Vermont? This episode explores the contributions and martyrdom of Joseph Smith and Hyrum. This episode will cover:

item.title: 060: Eternal Marriage; D&C and Church History 31
item.description: No human relationship is as focused on, celebrated, and debated as marriage. But what is the relationship between our marriage now and union in the eternities? What was the development between marriage in the Bible, early Church, and present day? Get ready for one of the most interesting episodes ever as a unique class discusses:

item.title: 059: Redeeming the Dead; D&C and Church History Lesson 30
item.description: In this episode we discuss the history and doctrine underlying the third mission of the Church–to redeem the dead. We will explore

item.title: 058: Building the Kingdom of God in Nauvoo, Illinois; D&C and Church History 29
item.description: The Nauvoo period of 1839-1846 proved both productive and tumultuous. This episode will explore this critical segment of Church history with an emphasis on the following points:

item.title: 057: Suffering; D&C and Church History 28
item.description: Why? Why me? Why my loved one? Why any of us? Where is God? There are no more poignant questions in life. This may prove to be the most important episode we even produce, as it explores our deepest question–why life is so hard. So unfair. So painful. This lesson and discussion will explore:

item.title: 056: Trials, Failure, and Purpose. D&C and Church History 27
item.description: This lesson doesn’t waste any time striking to the heart of difficult issues. This lesson will discuss such important topics as:

item.title: 055: Preaching the Gospel; D&C and Church History 26
item.description: So first, look at

item.title: 054: The Priesthood; D&C and Church History 25
item.description: We have already talked about the Restoration of the Priestood, and this lesson is the chance to dig into the nature of the priesthood. What exactly is it? What principles govern “the power of godliness”? During this lesson and discussion we will address:

item.title: 053: “Be Not Deceived, but Continue in Steadfastness”; D&C and Church History 24
item.description: It is time to address the tricky topic of individual “apostasy”–falling away from God and the Church. Are the two the same? Can you do one without the other? What does “being deceived” mean in this context? What is the relationship between doubt and apostasy?

item.title: 052: Learning by Study and also by Faith; D&C and Church History 23
item.description: In a sense, this lesson provides a foundation of all others. How do we understand ourselves, each other, and the world around us? How do we learn? What is the role of “study” and what is the role of “faith”? What are the strengths and limitations of each approach? This lesson will explore two primary questions:

item.title: 051: The Word of Wisdom; D&C and Church History 22
item.description: We are what we eat (Or even better in German, Man ist, was man isst). This proverb is quite literally true biologically, but also bears social truth–we are who we eat with. Food shapes us physically, spiritually, and socially. The Word of Wisdom is known as the “Lord’s law of health,” as well as creating social distinctions and emphasizing obedience. At the same time, too rarely do members consider the principles behind this requirement past the short list of “don’ts”. In this episode, we will discuss:

item.title: 050: The Second Coming; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 21
item.description: I know I often use superlatives relating to these lessons, but this topic might deserve a few. Is there any topic more thrilling and discussion provoking as the Second Coming? When I subbed youth Sunday School and asked for questions, the Second Coming was a requested topic. This is blockbuster movie material. And it has been.

item.title: 049: The Kingdoms of Glory; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 20
item.description: One of the gospel’s great contributions is its expansive, detailed, and powerful description of the Plan of Salvation–encompassing more than simply the afterlife, the scriptures describe multiple steps–the pre-existence, earth life, the spirit world, and then the kingdoms of glory. In this episode we will

item.title: 048: This Podcast’s for (and about) you!
item.description: A few months ago we put together a survey to find out who is listening to the podcast. We wanted to get to know you better, find out who you are, how you use the podcast, and what you thought of it. We wanted to know what we are doing well and what we can do better.

item.title: 047: The Plan of Salvation; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 19
item.description: “The Plan of Salvation” broad in scope, puts this life in perspective. It places us as the main character in a cosmic drama and represents one of Mormonism’s greatest contributions to religious thought. We are eternal, spiritual beings at the crucial junction in our path to perfection. At the same time, this current life is what we know best. How does this perspective influence our lives and decisions? How should it? How can we balance working toward eternal goals with quality of life now, this life and the life to come? This episode will tackle these critical issues.

item.title: 046: Introduction and Section 1, Text & Context 02
045: The Temple; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 18
item.description: Is there any aspect of Mormonism more simultaneously distinctive to outsiders, emphasized to insiders, yet misunderstood by pretty much everyone as the temple? These majestic edifices represent the pinnacle of Mormon worship and represent great sacrifice. Service at the temple involves high ritual and embodied worship to a degree unknown elsewhere in the faith. Yet far too often, members don’t feel empowered and illuminated in this House of God. The goal of this episode is to help listeners improve their relationship with the temple.

item.title: 044: Tithes and Fasting; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 17
item.description: This lesson is about sacrifices, one easier than the other–tithing and fasting (guess which is which). Money is one of those topics considered impolite to discuss, and the message that all we have belongs to God and therefore God should be able to command what we should do with it is certainly a bold and often unwelcome claim!

item.title: 043: “Thou Shalt … Offer Up Thy Sacraments upon My Holy Day”; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 16
item.description: The pace of modern life is unrelenting. Too many of us never stop. We never rest. We are always available, always on call–a text message away from work and distraction. There is wisdom is pausing, stopping for a moment, having times of quiet and reflection. And this is the purpose of the Sabbath, a term that means “to stop or rest.”

item.title: 042: “Seek Ye Earnestly the Best Gifts”; Doctrine & Covenants and Church History 15
item.description: Recurring Donation:

item.title: 041: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 14: The Law of Consecration
item.description: Why is “mine!” often among our first words? One of the most sensitive, difficult, and important questions involves resource allocation. Who gets what? Who has the right to what? Is there a minimum of resources that every person deserves? What level of inequality is ethical? What makes possession ethical?

item.title: 040: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 13: This Generation Shall Have My Word through You
039: Deeper Introduction to the Doctrine & Covenants, Text & Context 001
item.description: We are pleased to launch the companion podcast to Engaging Gospel Doctrine, Text & Context. Since the Doctrine & Covenants curriculum is topical and selective (students are only assigned to read about 30% of the D&C, and over 50 sections are skipped entirely. A full 25% of assigned readings come from D&C 20 and 76!). Given all this, we have decided to supplement the EGD podcast with Text & Context, which will explore the entire Doctrine & Covenants in greater detail, both textual and historical.

item.title: 038: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 12: The Gathering of My People
item.description: Belonging is one of our greatest human needs, and there aren’t many more poignant and powerful ideas than that of “coming home.” This lesson will explore the concept of “gathering”, or more poetically put, our Heavenly Parents bringing us together so we can help each other come home. We will discuss:

item.title: 037: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 11: The Field is White Already to Harvest
item.description: Along with majestic temples, nothing is more iconic of Mormonism than black-tagged missionaries. Missionary work has from the beginning played a vital role in the life of Mormonism. This lesson will discuss

item.title: 036: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 10: This Is My Voice unto All
item.description: The theme of this lesson is to “liken the scriptures to ourselves”, which means it is about nothing less than how to study the scriptures. How do we apply the scriptures to our lives? How do we determine what to focus on, what is valuable? What is our standard to determine which stories are good examples, and which bad?

item.title: 035: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 9: The Only True and Living Church
item.description: It is a shame we shorten this phrase to “The only true Church”, because I think “living” is a very important part of the statement. What does it mean to say the LDS Church is the “only true and living Church”? How do our Heavenly Parents interact with their children? What is the relationship between the different religions of the world? Why does it matter if we are a member of one religion rather than another?

item.title: 034: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 8: Restoration of the Priesthood
item.description: Restoration of the Priesthood

item.title: 033: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 7: First Gospel Principles and Ordinances
item.description: This lesson covers topics so frequently reviewed that we risk taking them for granted. We will dig deeply into the issues of faith in Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism, and the gift of the Holy Ghost. What is faith? Why does it need to be in Jesus Christ? How do we repent effectively? And the topic of repentance touches on key related issues–sin and forgiveness. Why is baptism necessary? Is it magic? What do we know about the Holy Ghost? What is the difference between the influence and Gift of the Holy Ghost?

item.title: 032: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 6: Revelation II
item.description: In this lesson we will discuss a topic of vital importance. How do we interpret revelation? How do we distinguish inspiration from God and our own thoughts, feelings, and desires? Once we can identify that we are receiving a prompting from a source greater than ourselves, how do we interpret it? How should we act on it? What is the relationship of personal revelation and teachings revealed through scripture and Church leaders?

item.title: 031: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 5: Revelation I
item.description: I would submit that the topic of the next two lessons is the single most important subject in all the gospel. Simply put, revelation is our access to everything else. It is our conduit and connection to spiritual life, to inspiration, to wisdom and guidance. It is the key to learning, to living well and serving others.

item.title: Gospel Doctrine Lesson 1: Introduction to the Doctrine & Covenants and Church History
030: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 4: The Book of Mormon
item.description: We spent all last year digging deeply into and “feasting upon” the Book of Mormon. Virtually all readers of the Book of Mormon would agree that this is the most important use of the Book of Mormon–to read it to nourish us spiritually and gain inspiration from it, to use it as a catalyst to expand our souls and improve our lives. These are the functions of the Book of Mormon.

item.title: 029: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 3: The First Vision.
item.description: This lesson covers the story that started it all… Joseph’s account of his first vision of God. I feel a close connection to this story since I am from the Palmyra stake! In this lesson we will:

item.title: 028: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 2: Jesus Christ
item.description: Jesus Christ permeates LDS Scripture in a unique way that members may not fully appreciate. Christians have the New Testament and especially the gospels, and the Old Testament with passages that are interpreted as prefiguring and prophesying the coming of Jesus. The Savior saturates modern scripture–virtually every chapter of the Book of Mormon mentions him, and in the Doctrine & Covenants, almost every section is written in the first person with Jesus as speaker!

item.title: 027: Doctrine & Covenants Lesson 1: Introduction
item.description: : Explanatory Introduction to the D&C; D&C 1; Introduction to

item.title: 026: Book of Mormon Lesson 48: Moroni 7-8; 10
item.description: “Come unto Christ”

item.title: 025: Book of Mormon Lesson 47: Moroni 1-6
item.description: “To Keep Them in the Right Way”

item.title: 024: Book of Mormon Lesson 46: Ether 7-15
item.description: “By Faith All Things Are Fulfilled”

item.title: 023: The Present and Future of Mormon Stories Sunday School
item.description: We have put out 22 episodes of Engaging Gospel Doctrine so far! As we wrap up the Book of Mormon and look forward to covering Doctrine & Covenants and Church History, this seemed like an ideal time to put out a mini-episode covering what we have accomplished, what we plan for next year, and what we need to make that happen.

item.title: 022: Book of Mormon Lesson 45: Ether 1-6
item.description: In this lesson we get to discuss the sealed portion of the Book of Mormon (which made up the bulk of the plates as Joseph described them)! What is contained in the sealed portion? What can we learn from the instructions regarding how to access them?

item.title: 021: Book of Mormon Lesson 44: Mormon 7-9
item.description: After Mormon’s final plea to the House of Israel, Moroni takes over the record. His despair and loneliness is palpable and touching in the beginning of Mormon 8. There are several thought provoking gems in these chapters about weakness, pride, caring for the needy, and theological points about the nature of God and judgment.

item.title: 020: Book of Mormon Lesson 43: Mormon 1-6; Moroni 9
item.description: Poignantly placed after the description of the Lehite utopia, these are the darkest, most disturbing chapters in the Book of Mormon. It seems a fitting time to wrestle with the human potential for evil, the reality of the terrible things we do to each other, almost as a rule. And after reading his life’s work, we get to meet Mormon as a main character. He reluctantly leads the Nephites in battle, refuses, and then returns. This is the end of the Book of Mormon civilization. In addition, we also read a haunting letter that I don’t think Mormon actually intended to include in the Book of Mormon (If you notice, Mormoni has an inferiority complex and actually contributes very little to the Book of Mormon. Most of his content is letters from his dad and then he edits Ether because his dad said he would and never was able to). We will also look at what we learn from Mormon’s shining example in the midst of such terrible circumstances.

item.title: 019: Book of Mormon Lesson 42: 3 Nephi 27-30; 4 Nephi
item.description: These chapters include an account of the happiest, most righteous, productive years in all of Book of Mormon history, the model utopian society that endured almost two hundred years after Jesus’ appearance. Unfortunately, we only read about that time period (which surpasses the time covered by Mosiah, Alma, Helaman, and 3 Nephi!) for eighteen brief verses. Why don’t we have more about this ideal period? How much could we learn from such a successful society? What can we apply from the details we have?

item.title: 018: Book of Mormon Lesson 41: 3 Nephi 22-26
item.description: These chapters function as a sermon and reflection about the scriptures. Jesus quotes from Isaiah 54 and Malachi 3-4. He recommends the writings of Isaiah and urges Nephi to supplement his own records. Then in a bittersweet twist, we are excluded from the climax of the story–Mormon tells us that Jesus reveals all things, that the mouths of children and infants are opened and they also teach the people. But he is forbidden to record these sublime teachings even though he wanted to.

item.title: 017: Book of Mormon Lesson 40: 3 Nephi 16, 20-21
item.description: Am I correct in concluding that these chapters fall in that category of scripture that most members read without comprehension? When we think “Isaiah chapters” 2 Nephi comes to mind, but 3 Nephi has its share as well, with some Micah thrown in.

item.title: 016: Book of Mormon Lesson 39: 3 Nephi 17-19
item.description: These chapters of the Book of Mormon contain some of the most moving and tender moments in all of scripture. Jesus heals the sick, one by one. The crowd weeps with joy. Jesus blesses little children and the scene becomes ineffable. Angels minister to the children and Jesus weeps. All take the sacrament and Jesus teaches about prayer and fellowship. The people work all night to bring even more to the place where Jesus will return. Jesus offers a parallel to his “Intercessory Prayer” of John 16 and prays for oneness and purity, and all are united in this spiritual experience.

item.title: 015: Book of Mormon Lesson 38: 3 Nephi 12-15
item.description: These chapters give a literal chance to “feast upon the words of Christ” since they consist almost exclusively of Jesus’ teachings. Chapters 12-14 parallel the Sermon on the Mount and focus on issues of the happy life (Beatitudes), discipleship, the relationship of Jesus to the Law of Moses, and proper prayer and fasting. Other points we will focus on include:

item.title: 014: Book of Mormon Lesson 37: 3 Nephi 8-11
item.description: 3 Nephi 11 is one of the most familiar chapters in Mormon scripture, shared by missionaries daily in countless languages. 3 Nephi 11-28 recount the personal ministry of Christ to the Lehites. Some of the most touching and powerful chapters in the Book of Mormon are found in this section.

item.title: 013: Book of Mormon Lesson 36: 3 Nephi 1-7
item.description: The beginning of 3 Nephi overflows with intense extremes as it describes the decades leading up to the appearance of Jesus to the Lehites. The sign of Jesus’ birth is given; people believe then disbelieve. A protracted war with the Gadianton robbers forces the people to prepare and unite. Society is rebuilt and then collapses. Discussion points will include:

item.title: 012: Book of Mormon Lesson 35: Helaman 13-16
item.description: These chapters are about Samuel the Lamanite posting to his wall (I know, bad joke, but some of us can relate to the stones and arrows). Samuel’s wall top preaching alternates between predictions of destruction, contrasting the Lamanite reaction to the truth, and prophesying concerning the coming of Christ. This lesson and discussion will focus on:

item.title: 011: Book of Mormon Lesson 34: Helaman 6-12
item.description: Pretty much everyone is depressed in these chapters. The prophet Nephi and editor Mormon both complain about human nature and the state of wickedness of the people at this time. This is where the Lamanites become more righteous than the Nephites. Highlights will include

item.title: 010: Book of Mormon Lesson 33: Helaman 1-5
item.description: Even with the impending ministry of Christ among the Nephites, Mormon sees this section as the beginning of the end (Hel. 2:13). Helaman is a dark book with powerful highlights. This is a bad time to be a chief judge, and a bad time for the Nephites. The Nephites expand their territory, but wars divide the land–the Nephites to the north, Lamanites to the south. In this lesson and discussion we will cover:

item.title: 009: Book of Mormon Lesson 32: Alma 53-63
item.description: The Book of Alma concludes with a bang as we read of wars of multiple fronts and severe internal turmoil and dissent. We can learn a great deal from the behavior of Moroni, Helaman, and their armies. And of course we can’t forget the 2000 stripling warriors and their mothers! There are several embedded letters in these accounts, from which we can draw many lessons. Look for an underappreciated gem in Pahoran’s response to Moroni, which provides a powerful model of interpersonal communication, trust, and conflict resolution.

item.title: 008: Book of Mormon Lesson 31: Alma 43-52
item.description: With this lesson we march into the “War chapters” of Alma. Sometimes it seems readers of the Book of Mormon don’t know quite what to do with these twenty odd chapters, but there are many important lessons and intriguing details we can glean.

item.title: 007: Book of Mormon Lesson 30: Alma 40-42
item.description: “The Great Plan of Happiness”

item.title: 006: Book of Mormon Lesson 29: Alma 36-39
item.description: This lesson and the next provide a precious and intimate window in the family life of Alma, one of the great Book of Mormon prophets. These chapters fit into the genre of “Testament”, which records the wisdom and blessings imparted by the patriarch of a family (unfortunately, we don’t have any records of a matriarch sharing her wisdom or blessings that I know of). Alma’s counsel to his sons Helaman, Shiblon, and Corianton provide us some of his final words in the Book of Mormon (before he gives his final blessings and mysteriously disappears in Alma 45).

item.title: 005: Book of Mormon Lesson 28: Alma 32-35
item.description: How many superstars of theology can we fit into a few chapters? Truth. Prayer. Atonement. These chapters contain some of the most memorable lessons and gems in the Book of Mormon. The “experiment upon the word” in Alma 32, Amulek’s powerful sermon on the Atonement and role of this life, as well as some overlooked treasures about prayer and mercy.

item.title: 004: Book of Mormon Lesson 27: Alma 30-31
item.description: I jokingly call this lesson “Apostates week”. The key exchanges this lesson are Alma vs. Korihor and then Alma and his companions vs. the Zoramites. We are going to push a bit in approach with this lesson, use these scriptures to challenge us a touch. Kind of like how so many enjoy likening ourselves to Nephi, but what can we learn by likening ourselves to Laman and Lemuel?

item.title: 003: Book of Mormon Lesson 26: Alma 23-29
item.description: These chapters tell of the dramatic conversion experience of an entire group of people, the so-called Anti-Nephi Lehis. We will discuss conversion and transformation. How do we change? What baggage do we bear from our upbringings that may hinder this transformation?

item.title: 002: Book of Mormon Lesson 25: Alma 17-22
item.description: These chapters begin the story of the missionary efforts of the sons of Mosiah. Ammon and Lamoni take center stage, but the Lamanite woman Abish and her queen play key roles and Mormon emphasizes the contrasts between missionary and conversion experiences by paralleling the stories Ammon and Lamoni, Aaron and Lamoni’s father.

item.title: 001: Introduction to Mormon Stories Sunday School
